==Necrophilia in Literature==
==Necrophilia in Literature==
â
In [[Toni Morrison]]'s [[novel]] [[[[Song of Solomon]]]], Macon Dead is explaining to his son Milkman about how he is disturbed by his wife, and Milkman's mother, Ruth Dead's relationship with her father, Dr. Foster. Shortly after Dr. Foster's death, Macon caught Ruth lying in bed, naked, with her father's corpse, while sucking on his fingers. It is not known whether she actually had sex with the dead Dr. Foster, but Macon seems to believe that she did.
+
In [[Toni Morrison]]'s [[novel]] ''[[Song of Solomon]]'', Macon Dead is explaining to his son Milkman about how he is disturbed by his wife, and Milkman's mother, Ruth Dead's relationship with her father, Dr. Foster. Shortly after Dr. Foster's death, Macon caught Ruth lying in bed, naked, with her father's corpse, while sucking on his fingers. It is not known whether she actually had sex with the dead Dr. Foster, but Macon seems to believe that she did.
